tit.e: Bitasen (low quality coins whose surfaces were worn away)
Bitasen (low quality coins whose surfaces were worn away)
tit.cmt: 以下説明が続くので、英語説明を削除しました。

sen.j: 鐚銭（びたせん）とは、日本の中世後期に流通した銭貨の中で、品質が著しく劣悪なものをいう。
sen.e: Bitasen was a coin of very poor quality among those circulated in late Medieval Japan.
Bitasen was a coin of very poor quality among those circulated during late Medieval Japan.
Bitasen was a coin of very poor quality among those circulated during late Medieval Japan.
It was also called as akusen.
sen.cmt: 「呼ばれる」の語を補って訳しました。
sen.e: They were also called akusen.
They were also called akusen.

sen.j: 日本では、鎌倉時代後期ごろから貨幣の流通が活発化したが、主に中国で鋳造された中国銭が流通していた。
sen.e: In Japan money circulation had become activated since about the late Kamakura Period, and Chinese coins minted and used in China were circulated predominantly.
sen.cmt: 「about」は不要かと思われましたが、原文に「ごろ」とありましたので加えました。
sen.e: In Japan money circulation had become active around the late Kamakura Period, and Chinese coins minted and used in China were predominantly circulated.
In Japan money circulation had become active around the late Kamakura period, and Chinese coins minted and used in China were predominantly circulated.

sen.j: これらの中国銭は、中国（北宋・元 (王朝)など）との貿易を通じて日本にもたらされたが、日本でもこれらの貨幣を私的に鋳造する者が現れた。
sen.e: These Chinese coins were brought into Japan through trades with China (of Baisong, Yuan Dynasty, for example) and such coins were come to be privately minted also in Japan.
These Chinese coins were brought into Japan through trade with China (during the Baisong, Yuan Dynasty, for example) and such coins also came to be privately minted in Japan.
These Chinese coins were brought into Japan through trade with China (during the Baisong, Yuan Dynasty, for example) and such coins also came to be privately minted in Japan.

sen.j: これを私鋳銭（しちゅうせん）という。
sen.e: These coins were called as Shichusen (private coinage).
These coins were called as Shichusen (private coinage).
These coins were called as Shichusen (private coinage).

sen.j: 私鋳銭は、一部が欠落したもの、穴が開いていないもの、字が潰れて判読できないものなど、非常に粗悪なものが多かった。
sen.e: The quality of the Shichusen was often very poor, for example a part of it was missed, it had no hole, and the letters on it were impossible to read.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The quality of Shichusen was often very poor, for example part of the detail was often missing, it had no hole, and the letters on it were impossible to read.
The quality of Shichusen was often very poor, for example part of the detail was often missing, it had no hole, and the letters on it were impossible to read.

sen.j: これらは商品経済の現場では嫌われる傾向が強かった。
sen.e: Thus, they tended to be disliked in the commodity economy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, they tended to be disliked in the commodity economy.
Thus, they tended to be disliked in the commodity economy.

sen.j: そのため、これら粗悪な銭貨は鐚銭と呼ばれ、一般の銭貨よりも低い価値とされるようになった。
sen.e: Therefore, those poor quality coins were called bitasen and considered to have less value than common coins.
Such poor quality coins were called bitasen and considered to have less value than common coins.
Such poor quality coins were called bitasen and considered to have less value than common coins.

sen.j: 室町時代に入り、明が日本との貿易用に鋳造した永楽通宝などが日本国内で流通するようになると、明の江南で作られた私鋳銭や、日本国内で作られた私鋳銭も次第に混入していった。
sen.e: As the Muromachi period begins and Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty) which was minted in China of the Ming Dynasity for trade with Japan became to be circulated in Japan, Shichusen minted in Konan (Jiangnan) of China and Shichusen minted in Japan were gradually got mingled with it.
sen.cmt: 「混入していった」→文字通り「were gradually got mingled with it」と訳しましたが、「became to be gradually circulated 」等の表現の方が原文の意味を表していると思われます。
sen.e: As the Muromachi period began and Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty) minted in China during the Ming Dynasity for trade with Japan were circulated in Japan, Shichusen minted in Konan (Jiangnan) China and Shichusen minted in Japan were gradually mingled together.

As the Muromachi period began and Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty) minted in China during the Ming Dynasty for trade with Japan were circulated in Japan, Shichusen minted in Konan (Jiangnan) China and Shichusen minted in Japan were gradually mingled together.

sen.j: そうした私鋳銭ばかりでなく南宋の戦時貨や明銭自体も不良銭が混じるなど品質劣悪なものが普通だったため、これらを総称して「悪銭」といった。
sen.e: Not only those Shichusen, but wartime coins of Chinese Southern Sung Dynasty and Minsen (bronze coins produced in Ming Dynasty) were got mingled with poor quality coins and were usually of poor quality, therefore they were collectively called as akusen.

Not only Shichusen, but wartime coins of the Chinese Southern Sung Dynasty and Minsen (bronze coins produced during Ming Dynasty) mingled with poor quality coins and were usually of poor quality, therefore they were collectively called akusen.

Not only Shichusen, but wartime coins of the Chinese Southern Sung Dynasty and Minsen (bronze coins produced during Ming Dynasty) mingled with poor quality coins and were usually of poor quality, therefore they were collectively called akusen.

sen.j: また、こうした悪銭は良質な「精銭」とくらべ低価値に設定されたり、支払時に受け取り拒否されることが多かった。
sen.e: Also, the akusen was sometimes set to lower price compared to "Seisen (refined coins)" of good quality, or often refused to be accepted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: これを撰銭（えりぜに）といった。
sen.e: This selection procedure was called Erizeni, Erisen, or Sensen(selecting refined coins).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処主語「これを」を「この選択の手順を」として訳しました。
sen.e: This selection procedure was called Erizeni, Erisen, or Sensen(selecting refined coins).
This selection procedure was called Erizeni.

sen.j: 時には撰銭が原因で殺傷事件が起こることもあった。
sen.e: Sometimes the Erizeni caused bloodshed event.
Sometimes Erizeni caused bloodshed.
Sometimes Erizeni caused bloodshed.

sen.j: だが、粗悪な渡来銭や私鋳銭の流通量は増大した。
sen.e: However, the turn volume of poor quality of Torai-sen (the importation of currency from China) and Shichusen increased.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the turn-over volume of poor quality of Torai-sen (the importation of currency from China) and Shichusen increased.
However, the turn-over volume of poor quality of Torai-sen (the importation of currency from China) and Shichusen increased.

sen.j: 後に室町幕府の14代征夷大将軍・足利義栄が将軍就任の御礼に朝廷に献上した銭貨や同じく織田信長が正親町天皇の儲君誠仁親王の元服の際に献上した銭貨が鐚銭ばかりであると非難された。
sen.e: It was criticized that the coins contained mostly akusen, the coins which Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, the Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) of the Muromachi bakufu presented to the Imperial court as the reward for the assumption of the Shogun, and coins which Nobunaga ODA presented at the ceremony of genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age) of Imperial Prince Sanehito, the chokun (crown prince) of Emperor Googimachi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was criticized that the coins contained mostly akusen, the coins which Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, the Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great unifying leader) the Muromachi bakufu presented to the Imperial court as a reward for the assumption of the Shogun, and coins which Nobunaga ODA presented at the ceremony of genpuku (celebration of one's coming of age) for Imperial Prince Sanehito, the chokun (crown prince) of Emperor Googimachi.

It was criticized that the coins contained mostly akusen, the coins which Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, the 14th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi bakufu presented to the Imperial court as a reward for the assumption of the Shogun, and coins which Nobunaga ODA presented at the ceremony of genpuku (celebration of one's coming of age) for Imperial Prince Sanehito, the chokun (crown prince) of Emperor Ogimachi.

sen.j: しかし、これは彼らが朝廷を軽視していたというよりも鐚銭ばかりが流通していて権力者でさえ良質な銭貨が入手困難であった事を示している。
sen.e: It means that so much akusen circulated that even powerful person could hardly obtain good quality coins, rather than that Yoshihide disrespected the Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: So many akusen circulated that even powerful persons could hardly obtain good quality coins, and Yoshihide was forced to disrespect the Imperial court.
So many akusen circulated that even powerful persons could hardly obtain good quality coins, and Yoshihide was forced to disrespect the Imperial court.

sen.j: そのため、16世紀になると室町幕府や守護大名、戦国大名たちは撰銭を禁ずる撰銭令（えりぜにれい）を発令して、円滑な貨幣流通を実現しようとした。
sen.e: Thus, in the 16th century the Muromachi bakufu, Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable), and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku Period tried to officially announce the ban on the Erizeni to achieve smooth money circulation.

Thus, in the sixteenth century the Muromachi bakufu, Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable), and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during the Sengoku Period tried to officially announce a ban on the Erizeni to achieve smoother money circulation.

sen.j: しかし、民衆の間では鐚銭を忌避する意識は根強く残存した。
sen.e: But there existed deep-rooted consciousness among common people to avoid bitasen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But there a deep-rooted consciousness existed among common people to avoid bitasen.

sen.j: 江戸時代に江戸幕府が安定した品質の寛永通宝を発行し、渡来銭や私鋳銭を厳しく禁ずるようになると、鐚銭は見られなくなり、撰銭も行われなくなっていった。
sen.e: As the Edo bakufu became to put Kanei Tsuho (coins) of stable quality into circulation and prohibited Torai-sen and Shichusen strongly, the akusen disappeared and Erizeni was not carried out any more.
